user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_close:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_close(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	(void)lbus;
	unsigned int i;

	for (i = 0; i < ldev->device.num_regions; i++) {
		metal_unmap(ldev->device.regions[i].virt,
			    ldev->device.regions[i].size);
	}
	if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->sdev) {
		sysfs_close_device(ldev->sdev);
		ldev->sdev = NULL;
	}
	if (ldev->fd >= 0) {
		close(ldev->fd);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_uio_dev_close:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
unsigned long *phys, offset = 0, size = 0
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (ldev->override) {
		sysfs_write_attribute(ldev->override, "", 1);
		ldev->override = NULL;
	}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: As written, the code fragment is reachable: when ldev->override is non-NULL the sysfs_write_attribute call and the subsequent assignment are executed, so Rule 2.1 is not violated here. A specific violation scenario would be if sysfs_write_attribute is non‑returning (e.g. declared with a noreturn attribute or it always calls exit()/longjmp/abort); in that case the statement ldev->override = NULL; would be unreachable and would violate Rule 2.1. Another possible violation scenario is if, by project-wide static analysis, ldev->override can be proven to be always NULL at this call site (making the entire if block unreachable).
